title: Test out that R works
text:
emp.data <- data.frame(
   emp_id = c (1:5), 
   emp_name = c("Rick","Dan","Michelle","Ryan","Gary"),
   salary = c(623.3,515.2,611.0,729.0,843.25), 
   
   start_date = as.Date(c("2012-01-01", "2013-09-23", "2014-11-15", "2014-05-11",
      "2015-03-27")),
   stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)
# Print the data frame.         
print(emp.data) 

  emp_id emp_name salary start_date
1      1     Rick 623.30 2012-01-01
2      2      Dan 515.20 2013-09-23
3      3 Michelle 611.00 2014-11-15
4      4     Ryan 729.00 2014-05-11
5      5     Gary 843.25 2015-03-27

title: Test Quarto Pixi CI w/ Multiple Environments
text:
This repository demonstrates how to create a of coding tutorial website that (hopefully) reduces barriers to user contributions.
Key characteristics:

The website is composed of static pages and is built by the Quarto publishing system.
Website updates are triggered by a GitHub Action.
Static files are hosted on GitHub pages.
Each tutorial has a independent coding environment, allowing the use of different versions of libraries (or even different languages). Versioned libraries are defined by a configuration file within the tutorial folder.

Example for Tutorial 1 which uses Python 3.11 and has the xkcd Python package installed.
Example for Tutorial 2 which uses Python 3.12 and has the shapely Python package installed.

To execute code within the tutorials, users can either:

Download the Jupyter notebook and install dependencies in a local environment.
Launch an online execution environment (GitHub Codespace) that includes a container configured for the tutorial (Container Configuration)

title: Test Quarto Pixi CI w/ Envs
text:
Tip with Title



In order to run the code in this tutorial, you can either download the notebook to run it on your local computer, or click the button below to run the tutorial in a GitHub Codespace.
